# List of _Billboard_ Hot 100 chart achievements and milestones

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![Billboard Hot 100
logo.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Billboard_Hot_100_logo.jpg/200px-
Billboard_Hot_100_logo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Billboard_Hot_100_logo.jpg)

This is a comprehensive listing that highlights **significant achievements and
milestones** based upon [_Billboard_ magazine](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\)
"Billboard \(magazine\)")'s singles charts, most notably the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"). This list spans the period
from the issue dated January 1, 1955 to present. The _Billboard_ Hot 100 began
with the issue dated August 4, 1958, and is currently the standard popular
music chart in the [United States](/wiki/United_States_of_America "United
States of America").

[Prior to the creation of the Hot 100](/wiki/Best_Sellers_In_Stores "Best
Sellers In Stores"), _Billboard_ published four singles charts: "Best Sellers
in Stores", "Most Played by Jockeys", "Most Played in Jukeboxes" and "The Top
100". These charts, which ranged from 20 to 100 slots, were phased out at
different times between 1957 and 1958. Though technically not part of the Hot
100 chart history, their data are included for computational purposes, and to
avoid unenlightening or misleading characterizations. All items listed below
are from the Hot 100 era, unless otherwise noted (pre-Hot 100 charts).

## All-Time Hot 100 achievements (1958–2015)

In 2008, for the 50th anniversary of the Hot 100, _Billboard_ magazine
compiled a ranking of the 100 best-performing songs on the chart over the 50
years, along with the best-performing artists.[1][2] In 2013, _Billboard_
revised the rankings for the chart's 55th anniversary edition.[3] In 2015,
_Billboard_ revised the rankings again.[4] Shown below are the top 10 songs
and top 10 artists over the 57-year period of the Hot 100, through October
2015. Also shown are the artists placing the most songs on the overall "all-
time" top 100 song list.

### Top 10 songs of All-Time (1958–2015)

Rank | Single | Year(s) released | Artist(s) | Peak and duration  
---|---|---|---|---  
1. | "[The Twist](/wiki/The_Twist_\(song\) "The Twist \(song\)")" |  1960, 1961* | [Chubby Checker](/wiki/Chubby_Checker "Chubby Checker") | #1 for 3 weeks  
2. | "[Smooth](/wiki/Smooth_\(song\) "Smooth \(song\)")" |  1999 | [Santana](/wiki/Santana_\(band\) "Santana \(band\)") featuring [Rob Thomas](/wiki/Rob_Thomas_\(musician\) "Rob Thomas \(musician\)") | #1 for 12 weeks  
3. | "[Mack the Knife](/wiki/Mack_the_Knife "Mack the Knife")" |  1959 | [Bobby Darin](/wiki/Bobby_Darin "Bobby Darin") | #1 for 9 weeks  
4. | "[How Do I Live](/wiki/How_Do_I_Live "How Do I Live")" |  1997 | [LeAnn Rimes](/wiki/LeAnn_Rimes "LeAnn Rimes") | #2 for 4 weeks  
5. | "[Party Rock Anthem](/wiki/Party_Rock_Anthem "Party Rock Anthem")" |  2011 | [LMFAO](/wiki/LMFAO "LMFAO") featuring [Lauren Bennett](/wiki/Lauren_Bennett "Lauren Bennett") & [GoonRock](/wiki/GoonRock "GoonRock") | #1 for 6 weeks  
6. | "[I Gotta Feeling](/wiki/I_Gotta_Feeling "I Gotta Feeling")" |  2009 | [The Black Eyed Peas](/wiki/The_Black_Eyed_Peas "The Black Eyed Peas") | #1 for 14 weeks  
7. | "[Macarena (Bayside Boys mix)](/wiki/Macarena_\(song\) "Macarena \(song\)")" |  1996 | [Los Del Rio](/wiki/Los_Del_Rio "Los Del Rio") | #1 for 14 weeks  
8. | "[Physical](/wiki/Physical_\(Olivia_Newton-John_song\) "Physical \(Olivia Newton-John song\)")" |  1981 | [Olivia Newton-John](/wiki/Olivia_Newton-John "Olivia Newton-John") | #1 for 10 weeks  
9. | "[You Light Up My Life](/wiki/You_Light_Up_My_Life_\(song\) "You Light Up My Life \(song\)")" |  1977 | [Debby Boone](/wiki/Debby_Boone "Debby Boone") | #1 for 10 weeks  
10. | "[Hey Jude](/wiki/Hey_Jude "Hey Jude")" |  1968 | [The Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles") | #1 for 9 weeks  
  
* – re-released

From 1955 to 2001, under _Billboard_ 's previous methodologies, only two singles ascended directly to #1 from a previous position beneath the Top 20: [The Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' "[Can't Buy Me Love](/wiki/Can%27t_Buy_Me_Love "Can't Buy Me Love")", which jumped from #27 to the top slot in April 1964, and [Brandy](/wiki/Brandy_Norwood "Brandy Norwood") and [Monica](/wiki/Monica_\(singer\) "Monica \(singer\)")'s "[The Boy Is Mine](/wiki/The_Boy_Is_Mine_\(song\) "The Boy Is Mine \(song\)")" which jumped from #23 to #1 in June 1998.

### Biggest drops off the Hot 100

  * From #4 – [Prince](/wiki/Prince_\(musician\) "Prince \(musician\)") and [The Revolution](/wiki/The_Revolution_\(band\) "The Revolution \(band\)") – "[Purple Rain](/wiki/Purple_Rain_\(song\) "Purple Rain \(song\)")"† (May 21, 2016)
  * From #8 – [Prince](/wiki/Prince_\(musician\) "Prince \(musician\)") – "[When Doves Cry](/wiki/When_Doves_Cry "When Doves Cry")"† (May 21, 2016)
  * From #9 – [Soko](/wiki/Soko_\(singer\) "Soko \(singer\)") – "[We Might Be Dead by Tomorrow](/wiki/We_Might_Be_Dead_by_Tomorrow "We Might Be Dead by Tomorrow")" (April 5, 2014)[57]
  * From #11 – [Jonas Brothers](/wiki/Jonas_Brothers "Jonas Brothers") – "[A Little Bit Longer](/wiki/A_Little_Bit_Longer_\(song\) "A Little Bit Longer \(song\)")" (August 30, 2008),[57][58] Taylor Swift – "[Mean](/wiki/Mean_\(song\) "Mean \(song\)")" (November 13, 2010),[59] [One Direction](/wiki/One_Direction "One Direction") – "[Diana](/wiki/Diana_\(One_Direction_song\) "Diana \(One Direction song\)")" (December 14, 2013),[60] Mariah Carey – "[All I Want for Christmas is You](/wiki/All_I_Want_for_Christmas_is_You "All I Want for Christmas is You")" (January 16, 2016)††[61]
  * From #12 – [Taylor Swift](/wiki/Taylor_Swift "Taylor Swift") – "[You Belong with Me](/wiki/You_Belong_with_Me "You Belong with Me")"* (November 29, 2008),[62] [Lady Gaga](/wiki/Lady_Gaga "Lady Gaga") – "[Hair](/wiki/Hair_\(Lady_Gaga_song\) "Hair \(Lady Gaga song\)")" (June 11, 2011),[63] One Direction – "[Midnight Memories](/wiki/Midnight_Memories_\(song\) "Midnight Memories \(song\)")" (December 14, 2013)[60]

† – "Purple Rain" and "When Doves Cry" reappeared on the Hot 100 for two weeks
in 2016, and the above reflects their re-entries only. When the songs
originally charted in 1984, their chart positions in their final week on the
Hot 100 were well below the top 10.

†† – A recurring holiday song charting during the Christmas season.

* – "You Belong with Me" later re-entered the Hot 100 as a single in 2009 to reach a peak of #2. The recurring song's final week on the Hot 100 was in 2010, when it was low as possible on the chart.

    Prior to 2008, the biggest drop off the Hot 100 was "[Nights in White Satin](/wiki/Nights_in_White_Satin "Nights in White Satin")" by [The Moody Blues](/wiki/The_Moody_Blues "The Moody Blues"), which ranked at #17 in its final week on the chart in December 1972. This high drop-off position was matched in January 1975 by "[Junior's Farm](/wiki/Junior%27s_Farm "Junior's Farm")" by [Paul McCartney and Wings](/wiki/Wings_\(band\) "Wings \(band\)"). The record went unchallenged for more than three decades, but every title listed above achieved its drop-off after just four weeks or less on the Hot 100. "Nights in White Satin" and "Junior's Farm" dropped off after 18 and 12 weeks, respectively.

Madonna | "[Like a Virgin](/wiki/Like_a_Virgin_\(song\) "Like a Virgin \(song\)")"[72]

  * † Pre-Hot 100 charts and Hot 100.
  * The biggest number-one listed by each artist reflects its overall performance on the Hot 100, as calculated by _Billboard_ , and may not necessarily be the single which spent the most weeks at #1 for the artist, such as Madonna's "Like a Virgin" (six weeks at #1, compared to seven for "[Take a Bow](/wiki/Take_a_Bow_\(Madonna_song\) "Take a Bow \(Madonna song\)")"), Mariah Carey's "We Belong Together" (fourteen weeks at #1, compared to sixteen for her duet with Boyz II Men, "One Sweet Day") and Michael Jackson's duet with Paul McCartney, "Say Say Say" (six weeks at #1, compared to seven for both his solo singles "Billie Jean" and "[Black or White](/wiki/Black_or_White "Black or White")").
  * _Billboard_ now credits the dual #1 Presley single "Don't Be Cruel"/"Hound Dog" as a single chart entity. "Don't Be Cruel"/"Hound Dog" spent 11 weeks at #1, "Hound Dog" for 6 weeks, "Don't Be Cruel" for 5 weeks. Many chart statisticians however, such as [Joel Whitburn](/wiki/Joel_Whitburn "Joel Whitburn") still lists Presley as having 18 number ones.

### Age records

  * [Louis Armstrong](/wiki/Louis_Armstrong "Louis Armstrong") (age 7004229240000000000♠62 years, 279 days) is the oldest artist to top the Hot 100. He set that record with "Hello, Dolly!" on May 9, 1964.
  * [Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher") (age 7004192900000000000♠52 years, 297 days) is the oldest female artist to top the Hot 100. She set the record with "Believe" on March 13, 1999. The previous record holder was [Grace Slick](/wiki/Grace_Slick "Grace Slick") of [Starship](/wiki/Starship_\(band\) "Starship \(band\)"), who was 7004173230000000000♠47 years, 156 days old when their hit "Nothing's Gonna Stop Us Now" began its two-week reign on April 4, 1987.
  * Michael Jackson (age 7003417300000000000♠11 years, 155 days) is the youngest artist to top the Hot 100. He achieved the record, as part of the Jackson 5, with "I Want You Back" on January 31, 1970.
  * [Stevie Wonder](/wiki/Stevie_Wonder "Stevie Wonder") (age 7003483700000000000♠13 years, 89 days) is the youngest solo artist to top the Hot 100. He set the record with "Fingertips Pt. 2" on August 10, 1963.
  * [Little Peggy March](/wiki/Little_Peggy_March "Little Peggy March") (age 7003552800000000000♠15 years, 50 days) is the youngest female artist to top the Hot 100. The song which established this record for her was "I Will Follow Him", which reached #1 on April 27, 1963.
  * [Tony Bennett](/wiki/Tony_Bennett "Tony Bennett"), at 7004311050000000000♠85 years, 59 days old, is the oldest living artist to chart. His song "Body and Soul", a duet with [Amy Winehouse](/wiki/Amy_Winehouse "Amy Winehouse"), ranked at #87 on October 1, 2011.
  * French-born [Jordy Lemoine](/wiki/Jordy_Lemoine "Jordy Lemoine") (age 7003198300000000000♠5 years, 156 days) is the youngest artist to chart on the Hot 100. He established the record when his song "Dur dur d'être bébé! (It's Tough to Be a Baby)", where he is credited simply as Jordy, entered the chart on June 19, 1993.[129][130]

### Gap records

  * The longest gap between #1 hits on the Hot 100 for an artist is 7003912100000000000♠24 years, 355 days by Cher. Her single "Believe" hit #1 on March 13, 1999, her first time on top since "Dark Lady" on March 23, 1974.
  * Cher also holds the record gap between first and most recent #1 on the Hot 100 over the longest period of time: 7004122850000000000♠33 years, 232 days. The first of three weeks at #1 for "I Got You Babe" by Sonny & Cher was August 14, 1965. The last week at #1 for Cher's "Believe" was April 3, 1999.
  * The record for the longest wait from an artist's Hot 100 debut entry to its first #1 belongs to Santana, with 30 years between the time he first cracked the Hot 100 with "Jingo" (October 25, 1969) and the first of 12 weeks at #1 with "Smooth," featuring Rob Thomas (October 23, 1999).
  * When the Tony Bennett and [Amy Winehouse](/wiki/Amy_Winehouse "Amy Winehouse") duet "[Body and Soul](/wiki/Body_and_Soul_\(song\)#Tony_Bennett_and_Amy_Winehouse_duet "Body and Soul \(song\)")" debuted at #87 for the week of October 1, 2011,[131] Bennett became the artist with the longest overall span of singles on the Hot 100 – 7004194160000000000♠53 years, 58 days on account of his single "[Young and Warm and Wonderful](/wiki/Young_and_Warm_and_Wonderful "Young and Warm and Wonderful")" which appeared at #59 on the very first edition of the Hot 100, dated August 4, 1958.

## Selected additional Hot 100 achievements

  * The first #1 song on the Hot 100 was "[Poor Little Fool](/wiki/Poor_Little_Fool "Poor Little Fool")" by [Ricky Nelson](/wiki/Ricky_Nelson "Ricky Nelson") (August 4, 1958).
  * The #1 song in the first week _Billboard_ incorporated sales and airplay data from [Nielsen SoundScan](/wiki/Nielsen_SoundScan "Nielsen SoundScan") and [Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems](/wiki/Nielsen_Broadcast_Data_Systems "Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems") was "[Set Adrift on Memory Bliss](/wiki/Set_Adrift_on_Memory_Bliss "Set Adrift on Memory Bliss")" by [P.M. Dawn](/wiki/P.M._Dawn "P.M. Dawn") (November 30, 1991).
  * The #1 song in the first week _Billboard_ allowed songs without a commercial single release to chart on the Hot 100 was "[I'm Your Angel](/wiki/I%27m_Your_Angel "I'm Your Angel")" by [R. Kelly](/wiki/R._Kelly "R. Kelly") and [Céline Dion](/wiki/Celine_Dion "Celine Dion") (December 5, 1998). Though the song was making its first appearance on the Hot 100 that week, _Billboard_ did not consider it a debut at #1, since it appeared on unpublished test charts prior to the allowance of airplay-only songs on the main chart.[151] "I'm Your Angel" also entered the Hot 100 Singles Sales chart that week at #1,[152] so it would have been ineligible to chart on the Hot 100 before then.
  * The first "airplay-only" song to reach #1 (no points from a commercial single release) was "[Try Again](/wiki/Try_Again_\(Aaliyah_song\) "Try Again \(Aaliyah song\)")" by [Aaliyah](/wiki/Aaliyah "Aaliyah") (June 17, 2000).
  * [Drake](/wiki/Drake_\(rapper\) "Drake \(rapper\)") holds the record for the most entries in the Hot 100 during a one-week period, with 24 on the April 8, 2017 chart.[104] The Beatles had long held this record, occupying 14 positions on the Hot 100 dated April 11, 1964, a feat unmatched for nearly 51 years. On March 7, 2015, Drake tied the Beatles mark,[153] and he equaled it again on October 17 that year.[154] [Justin Bieber](/wiki/Justin_Bieber "Justin Bieber") then reset the record to 17 on December 5, 2015,[155] before Drake reclaimed the record with 20 on May 21, 2016.[154]
  * Drake also holds the record for the most debuting entries on a Hot 100 chart by any artist, with 21 on April 8, 2017.[104]
  * [Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9 "Beyoncé") is the record-holder among female artists for the most simultaneous entries in the Hot 100, with 12 on the May 14, 2016 chart.[156]
  * The Beatles are the only artists to simultaneously hold the top 2 spots on the _Billboard_ Hot 100 singles chart and _Billboard_ 200 albums chart. They achieved this feat for nine consecutive weeks, from February 29, 1964, to April 25, 1964. For the first five weeks of that run, through March 28, 1964, "[I Want to Hold Your Hand](/wiki/I_Want_to_Hold_Your_Hand "I Want to Hold Your Hand")" and "[She Loves You](/wiki/She_Loves_You "She Loves You")" were the #1 and #2 singles (which swapped positions during March 1964), while _[Meet the Beatles!](/wiki/Meet_the_Beatles! "Meet the Beatles!")_ and _[Introducing... The Beatles](/wiki/Introducing..._The_Beatles "Introducing... The Beatles")_ held the top 2 spots on the albums charts. For the remaining weeks of the run, "[Can't Buy Me Love](/wiki/Can%27t_Buy_Me_Love "Can't Buy Me Love")" and their cover of "[Twist and Shout](/wiki/Twist_and_Shout "Twist and Shout")" were the #1 and #2 singles, while _Meet the Beatles!_ and _Introducing... The Beatles_ continued their reign as the top 2 albums.[157][158]
  * Barry Gibb, Robin Gibb, John Lennon, and Paul McCartney hold the record of writing all of the Top 3 singles for one week. The Gibbs co-wrote the top 3 singles for the week of March 18, 1978 – #1 "Night Fever" and #2 "Stayin' Alive" for the Bee Gees, and #3 "[Emotion](/wiki/Emotion_\(Samantha_Sang_song\) "Emotion \(Samantha Sang song\)")" for [Samantha Sang](/wiki/Samantha_Sang "Samantha Sang"). Lennon and McCartney co-wrote the top 3 singles for the week of March 14, 1964 – #1 "I Want to Hold Your Hand", #2 "She Loves You", and #3 "[Please Please Me](/wiki/Please_Please_Me_\(song\) "Please Please Me \(song\)")", all for The Beatles. They continued this record the following week of March 21, 1964, when "She Loves You" switched places with "I Want to Hold Your Hand".
  * The Black Eyed Peas hold the record for the longest uninterrupted time at #1 on the Hot 100, a total of 26 consecutive weeks from April to October 2009. "Boom Boom Pow" spent the first 12 weeks on top, with "I Gotta Feeling" taking over for the remaining 14 weeks.[159] Prior to August 2009, Usher held this record, spending 19 consecutive weeks on top of the chart in 2004 with "Yeah!" (12 weeks at #1) and "Burn" (first 7 of its 8 total weeks at #1).[160]
  * Taylor Swift holds the all-time record for most top ten debuts on the Hot 100, with 14.[161]
  * On December 4, 2010, Rihanna's "[Only Girl (In the World)](/wiki/Only_Girl_\(In_the_World\) "Only Girl \(In the World\)")" reached the top spot two weeks after "[What's My Name?](/wiki/What%27s_My_Name%3F_\(Rihanna_song\) "What's My Name? \(Rihanna song\)")", becoming the first time in Hot 100 history that an album's debut single hit #1 after the second single did.[162]
  * Ed Sheeran became the first artist to debut more than one song in the top 10 for the same week. On the chart dated January 28, 2017, "[Shape of You](/wiki/Shape_of_You "Shape of You")" debuted at #1, while "[Castle on the Hill](/wiki/Castle_on_the_Hill_\(song\) "Castle on the Hill \(song\)")" entered at #6.[163] Drake is the only other artist to have achieved this feat, doing so on April 8, 2017.[104]
  * Drake holds the record for being on the Hot 100 for the most consecutive weeks. He placed at least one song, either in a lead or featured role, on every chart from his debut on May 23, 2009, to August 19, 2017, for a total of 431 weeks in a row.[164]
